Don't worry about not being able to add the site via the Configuration 
Manager, I gave you wrong "directions".
I realized that when you add a site, the site must have a specific directory 
structure, and a marker file as well. In most cases, it is for existing sites, 
not for creating new.

As for your actual problem, I still don't understand what's going on.
Try the following (installing from the command line):

Exit eclipse, then run the following command from inside the eclipse directory:

java -cp startup.jar org.eclipse.core.launcher.Main -applicationo 
rg.eclipse.update.core.standaloneUpdate -command install -from 
http://p4eclipse.sourceforge.net/site -featureId 
net.sourceforge.perforce.win32 -version 0.6.2
Append "-nosplash -consolelog -debug" to the above command as well.

Ok, I've tried your command line. But I'm sitting behind a firewall.
I've tried the -DproxyHost, etc. flags with no success.

How can I tell your command to use the proxy and not connect directly?

With best regards

Marcel Odendahl.

It appears that the parameters used are:

-Dorg.eclipse.update.core.proxy.host
-Dorg.eclipse.update.core.proxy.port
-Dorg.eclipse.update.core.proxy.enable

Correction: those properties (org.eclipse.update.core.port/host/enable) are 
not system properties, but plugin properties.
You can set in a file called preferences.ini inside the 
org.eclipse.update.core plugin.

I released some code fixes for proxies that would allow you passing the 
standard java http.proxyHost and http.proxyPort as parameters on the command 
line and have the update manager use them.
I am closing this bug. Please re-open if you still see any issues.
